column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning.; ; Examples
column5: of documents that may be protected under FOIA exemption 5 include:; ; 1. Deliberative process privilege: This exemption protects documents that are part of the decision-making process within an agency. These documents may include internal memos, drafts, and other materials that are used to formulate policy or make decisions. The purpose of this exemption is to encourage open and frank discussions within agencies without fear of public disclosure.; ; 2. Attorney-client privilege: This exemption protects communications between an agency and its attorneys that are made for the purpose of seeking legal advice or representation. This exemption is intended to protect the confidentiality of legal advice and strategy.; ; 3. Work product privilege: This exemption protects documents that are created in anticipation of litigation or other legal proceedings. This exemption is intended to protect the confidentiality of an agency's legal strategy and analysis.; ; Based on the above examples, it is possible that certain documents may be protected under FOIA exemption 5. However, it ultimately depends on the specific content and context of the documents in question. If the documents are part of the decision-making process, seek legal advice, or are created in anticipation of litigation, they may be protected under exemption 5. It is important to note that even if a document is protected under exemption 5, there may be other exemptions or limitations that apply to its disclosure.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning.; ;     • HOPE Scholarship. A maximum $1,500 credit for the first two years of postsecondary education. Students attending on at least a half-time basis would receive a 100% credit for the first $1,000 of tuition and required fees and a 50% credit for up to the next $1,000. For example, a student attending a community college with tuition costs of $1,400 would receive a $1,200 HOPE Scholarship. Scholarships would be phased out for joint filers with income between $80,000 and $ I 00,000, and for single filers with income between $50,000 and $70,000. After 2002, the HOPE Scholarship increases to a I00% credit for the first $ I,500 and a 50% credit for the next $1,000 of tuition and required fees.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning.; ;     • Employer-Provided Education Benefits. Extends permanently Section 127 of the tax code, which allows . people to exclude $5,250 of employer-provided education benefits from their taxable income. Eligibility for graduate education benefits would be reinstated retroactively back to June 30, 1996, with both undergraduate and graduate education eligible in the future. Additionally, a I 0% employer credit for small business training is included. This credit would apply to payments made to third parties to cover expenses of education for employees under employer-provided education assistance programs. The credit would be available to employers with average annual gross receipts of $10 million or less for the prior three years.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning.; ;     • Student Loan Interest Deduction. Allows a deduction for up to $2,500 per year of interest on education loans for expenses of students enrolled at an institution of higher education. The deduction would be allowed for the first 60 months interest is due on a loan. The deduction would phase out for taxpayers making between $45,000 and $65,000 ($65,000 and $85,000 for married taxpayers filing jointly). This deduction would be available even if the taxpayer does not itemize deductions.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning.; ;     • Community Service Loan Forgiveness. It summarizes recent advances in molecular and behavioral neuroscience, in particular newly elaborated systems of transmitters, receptors, and antagonists - all illuminating the physiological effects of cannabinoids. The Institute of Medicine has addressed all issues that ONDCP requested be examined, including: the science base and gaps in scientific knowledge regarding use of marijuana for medicinal purposes; scientific information about marijuana's mechanism of action; peer-reviewed literature on the uses of marijuana; and costs associated with various forms of the component chemical compounds in marijuana and other pharmacotherapies for special medical conditions. Explain your reasoning.; ; I spent a lot of time haranguing, cajoling, trying to persuade, sometimes putting brutal pressure on countries where drugs are grown or processed, or through which drugs pass, trying to get people to stop doing things that send drugs  to us.  And we've had some success. We supported remarkable efforts by the Coast Guard, for example, to cut off drugs before they get to this country. But  we can never  cut  off  the  whole  flow.  And every time I'd do this, some leader of a country where drugs are grown will say: You know, Mr. President, you're right,  we have a lot of poor farmers in our country, and I wish they'd grow something else. But America has four percent of the  world's people and you're buying almost 50 percent of the world's drugs. Nobody is making you buy those drugs. So you can say whatever you want to us.  If  you just  said tomorrow  -- everybody  in America said, we're not going to buy any more drugs, all our farmers would immediately start to grow something legal and good. And that's true. (Applause.)

He said,  well, in high school; I started using marijuana and drinking beer. I said, how often? He said, every day. And I thought to myself, what kind of family member was I? And these things make you do really bad things. They make you abuse other people. Most of the people selling drugs on the street are out there  supporting  their  own  habits. So you take other people, people who are basically good people, and you turn them into animals, because they don't care what they do to anybody else because they've got to get the money if they have to destroy somebody else, so they can keep feeding their own habits. They destroy  families.  Mothers  who love their  sons wind up neglecting them, abusing them, walking away, weakening the family. Everybody gets hurt. Nobody in America is free of this. Not the President. Not any community, any school, any church, any neighborhood.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? The Department of Justice ["DOJ"] is attempting to ensure that the Sentencing Commission's Guidelines, currently in the drafting phase, reflect the legislative intent to increase penalties substantially for methamphetamine offenses.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning.; ;  One sad example of the dangers of methamphetamine production occurred in Perris, California on April 19, 1997, when a fire exploded in a trailer home seriously burning two young children, ages 4 and 6. The investigators determined that the fire was caused by the mother of the two children attempting to extract pseudoephedrine from certain pharmaceutical tablets.  The mother was subsequently arrested on suspicion of manufacturing methamphetamine and four counts of child endangerment, and more than 1,400 bottles of pseudoephedrine were recovered from the scene. Such dangers must be addressed -- not only by law enforcement authorities -- but also in cooperation with public health and safety officials.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Two of the defendants are charged as principal administrators of a continuing criminal enterprise, the drug kingpin statute that is reserved for the highest echelon of participants within a drug trafficking organization.    The methamphetamine and marijuana, which originated in Juarez, Mexico, had been packed into molded fiberglass containers and loaded into the trailer at a warehouse in El Paso, and was being transported to Chicago.   This OCDETF investigation was conducted by agents of the DEA and U.S. Customs Service, as part of the Southwest Border Initiative.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? DEA has also joined forces with organizations -- such as the Partnership for a Drug Free America and other entities representing prevention, law enforcement, treatment, and medical professionals -- to provide information and lectures on substance abuse to communities throughout the United States.   DEA's Operation VELOCITY is producing a videotape production to educate law enforcement officers on some of the chemical hazards of clandestine laboratory investigations.  Clandestine laboratory awar.eness posters are being distributed to state and local clandestine laboratory enforcement teams throughout the United States.
column5: It is possible that some portions of this information could be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. For example, if the DEA has internal communications discussing the funding of the methamphetamine hotline or the production of the Operation VELOCITY videotape, those communications could potentially be protected. However, the general information about the hotline, partnerships with other organizations, and distribution of posters would likely not be protected under exemption 5 as they do not involve privileged communications.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning.; ;  Two Methamphetamine Conferences have been scheduled to assess progress and solicit input from the States for revision of the National Methamphetamine Strategy. The first, a western regional conference, was held on January 12-13, 1997 in San Francisco, California. This Conference was co-hosted by Senator Feinstein, and over 160 persons participated from six states; it was well-received.    The second Conference will take place on May 28-30, 1997 in Omaha, Nebraska and will be co-hosted by Senator Kerrey.
column5: No, this information would not be protected under FOIA exemption 5. Exemption 5 applies to inter-agency or intra-agency communications that are privileged, such as attorney-client communications or deliberative process materials. The information provided in this passage does not appear to be related to any such communications and therefore would not be exempt from disclosure under exemption 5.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning.; ;  These Conferences bring together policy makers, researchers, public interest groups, law enforcement, treatment, and prevention specialists to share information, increase understanding, and make recommendations on improving the nation's strategic response to this growing problem.    The Attorney General, Director of the National Institute of Justice ["NIJ"], and the Director of the National Institute of Drug Abuse ["NIDA"] will address this National Conference.
column5: It is possible that this information could be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. The conferences may involve discussions of sensitive policy matters or research findings that are not yet ready for public release. Additionally, the presence of high-level officials like the Attorney General and directors of government agencies suggests that the information being shared is of a confidential nature. However, without more specific information about the content of the conferences, it is difficult to make a definitive determination about whether exemption 5 would apply.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning.; ;     IV. International Efforts.
column5: It is not possible to determine whether the statement "IV. International Efforts" would be protected under FOIA exemption 5 without additional context. FOIA exemption 5 protects inter-agency or intra-agency memorandums or letters that would not be available by law to a party other than an agency in litigation with the agency. It is unclear whether "IV. International Efforts" refers to such a document or communication.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning.; ; Mexico-based organizations are now predominant in methamphetamine and precursor chemicals trafficking.  The Administration has been advising and training our foreign counterparts -- particularly in Mexico -- and on ways to curb methamphetamine trafficking.    They have been encouraged to implement meaningful controls to prevent smuggling and diversion of precursor chemicals.   Further, the Administration has been augmenting the role of the existing U.S.-Mexico working group on precursor chemicals, which oversees the training of Mexican officials and the mechanics of the exchange of chemical information with Mexico.
column5: The statement would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. The statement discusses the Administration's efforts to advise and train foreign counterparts, particularly in Mexico, on ways to curb methamphetamine trafficking and prevent smuggling and diversion of precursor chemicals. This information could be considered privileged because it relates to the government's internal decision-making processes and deliberations on how to address a specific issue. Additionally, disclosing this information could potentially harm ongoing efforts to combat drug trafficking and compromise sensitive diplomatic relationships with Mexico.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning.; ;     V. Demand Reduction Efforts.
column5: It is not possible to determine whether "V. Demand Reduction Efforts" would be protected under FOIA exemption 5 without additional context. FOIA exemption 5 protects inter-agency or intra-agency communications that are privileged or confidential, such as attorney-client communications or deliberative process materials. If "V. Demand Reduction Efforts" refers to such communications, it may be protected under exemption 5. However, if it refers to factual information or other non-privileged materials, it would not be protected under exemption 5.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning.; ;         A. Education and Prevention.
column5: No, "Education and Prevention" would not be protected under FOIA exemption 5. Exemption 5 applies to inter-agency or intra-agency communications that are privileged, such as attorney-client communications or deliberative process privilege. "Education and Prevention" does not fall under any of the categories of privileged communication that are protected under exemption 5.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning.; ;  The Administration continues to stress the need for public awareness with respect to the methamphetamine threat.    All segments of our society -- including law enforcement, teachers, judges, social workers, and public health officials -- should learn about the hazards posed by this drug and should proclaim its dangers to America's youth.
column5: No, this statement would not be protected under FOIA exemption 5. Exemption 5 pertains to privileged communications within the executive branch, such as those involving attorney-client privilege or deliberative process privilege. This statement does not fall under either of those categories and is not related to any privileged communication.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning.; ;  DOJ has worked to launch the Methamphetamine Interagency Task Force, to examine the best ways to reduce demand of methamphetamine, as required by the Act.  This Task Force which will bring together experts from all over the country to design, implement, and evaluate the education, prevention, and treatment practices and strategies of the Federal government with respect to methamphetamine and other synthetic stimulants.
column5: It is possible that this information could be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. If the DOJ has internal communications discussing the development of the Methamphetamine Interagency Task Force, including discussions about strategy and implementation, those communications could be considered privileged and exempt from disclosure. However, if the information is already publicly available or does not contain privileged communications, it would not be protected under exemption 5.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning.; ;         B. Collection Of Dat .

Without more information about the nature of the data collection, it is impossible to determine if it would fall under one of these categories.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning.; ; The NIJ is also expanding its DUF program from 23 to over 40 sites in 1997, and the program will be renamed the Arrestee Drug Abuse Monitoring ["ADAM"].    This program is important in tracking the spread of an emerging drug like methamphetamine and will  · provide timely data about drug trends from a select population. The next DUF Report on methamphetamine use is due to be released in May 1997.
column5: The passage would not be protected under FOIA exemption 5. Exemption 5 protects inter-agency or intra-agency communications that are part of the decision-making process. This information does not fall under the scope of exemption 5.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Twenty-five federal districts have agreed to test arrestees for drug use -- in most cases, prior to the arrestee's first appearance before a judicial officer.  The Administration hopes to expand this drug testing, sanctions, and treatment program to an additional 25 districts in 1998.
column5: No, this information would not be protected under FOIA exemption 5. column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning.; ;         C. Treatment Protocol for Methamphetamine Abuse.
column5: It is possible that the Treatment Protocol for Methamphetamine Abuse could be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. If the protocol was developed through internal agency deliberations or contains confidential communications between agency officials, it may be considered privileged and exempt from disclosure. However, if the protocol is a publicly available document or was developed through a collaborative process with external stakeholders, it may not be protected under exemption 5. Ultimately, the determination of whether the protocol is exempt from disclosure would depend on the specific circumstances surrounding its development and distribution.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning.; ; As of today, there is no specific treatment protocol for methamphetamine.   Because chronic methamphetamine users frequently suffer major changes in neural chemical activity and brain functions, treatment periods for methamphetamine users can be much longer and more extensive than treatments for other abused drugs.
column5: No, the statement would not be protected under FOIA exemption 5. FOIA exemption 5 protects inter-agency or intra-agency communications that are part of the decision-making process. The statement provided does not involve any communication between agencies or within an agency, nor does it relate to any decision-making process. It is a general statement about the lack of a specific treatment protocol for methamphetamine and the challenges of treating chronic methamphetamine users. Therefore, it would not be protected under FOIA exemption 5.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning.; ;  Administration personnel are continuing to work with medical researchers and treatment practitioners to understand the behaviors that threaten law enforcement and the measures that will be taken to restrain and not further injure the user. Government authorities have participated in public health conferences to determine the direction that medical and scientific research should take with respect to physical and chemical effects of methamphetamine, medical complications associated with its abuse, and treatment and prevention methods.
column5: Yes, this statement would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between government agencies. The statement describes ongoing discussions and collaborations between administration personnel, medical researchers, and treatment practitioners, which could be considered privileged information related to the agency's decision-making process. Additionally, the mention of participation in public health conferences could also be considered privileged information related to the agency's policy development and strategy.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning.; ;  In addition, NIJ has begun to formulate a demonstration plan that would test drug treatment protocols for methamphetamine­ involved persons in the criminal justice systems.    Drawing upon the expertise of drug treatment professionals, NIJ hopes to support the development of effective methamphetamine treatment technologies as the criminal justice system confronts the continuing challenges of drugs and crime.
column5: It is possible that this information could be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. The language used suggests that NIJ is in the process of formulating a plan, which could be considered pre-decisional and deliberative. Additionally, the mention of seeking input from drug treatment professionals could be seen as internal agency communications. However, it ultimately depends on the specific context and circumstances surrounding the information.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning.; ; NIDA held a research conference in June 1996 to study treatment.    NIDA research has dramatically increased our knowledge about the neural basis for psycho-stimulant drugs like methamphetamine and the neuro-toxic potential of these stimulants.        Methamphetamine has been shown to be a powerfully addictive stimulant causing physical and behavioral changes. NIDA currently supports $20 million in research to understand the epidemiology of methamphetamine use, its mechanism of action and effects on brain functions, behavioral consequences of methamphetamine, and treatment and prevention implications and approaches.
column5: No, this information would not be protected under FOIA exemption 5. Exemption 5 applies to inter-agency or intra-agency communications that are privileged or confidential, such as attorney-client communications or deliberative process materials. The information provided in this example is factual information about NIDA's research and funding, and does not appear to be privileged or confidential.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning.; ; NIDA is also supporting research entitled "Integrating Treatments for Methamphetamine Abuse:    A Psychosocial Perspective."    Their findings suggest that there is a measurable degree of response by methamphetamine abusers to psychosocial· intervention and that the general treatment experience, as reflected by the attendance of therapeutic sessions, breaks in treatment participation, and total treatment received does not differ significantly between methamphetamine and cocaine users.
column5: No, the statement would not be protected under FOIA exemption 5. Exemption 5 protects inter-agency or intra-agency communications that are privileged or contain deliberative process material. The statement provided does not appear to be a communication between agencies or within an agency, nor does it contain any privileged or deliberative information. It is simply a summary of research findings, which would not be exempt from disclosure under FOIA.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning.; ; The National Institutes of Health ["NIH"] similarly are conducting an in-depth study of the methamphetamine user and will present its preliminary findings at a national conference.    NIH also plans to expand its drug testing program to improve data collection.
column5: No, the statement would not be protected under FOIA exemption 5. FOIA exemption 5 protects inter-agency or intra-agency communications that are part of the decision-making process. column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning.; ; Furthermore, the Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration ["SAMHSA"] has two major proposals to investigate the implications of methamphetamine abuse. The first proposal will evaluate the effects of methamphetamine on pregnancy and post-natal development; this type of information is currently obtained anecdotally.    The proposed project will examine retrospectively the association of methamphetamine use during pregnancy with the medical and developmental consequences found among two cohorts of pre-natally methamphetamine-exposed children born in 1989 and 1990.        SAMHSA's second project will study the effects on suppressing methamphetamine demand at the community level with intensified drug-testing in the criminal justice system and at the workplace, combined with media campaigns and enhanced treatment for methamphetamine dependence.
column5: It is possible that some portions of these proposals could be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications and deliberative process. Specifically, any internal communications or drafts related to the development of these proposals could potentially be withheld if they are deemed part of the agency's decision-making process and not yet finalized. However, any final reports or findings from these projects would likely not be protected under exemption 5 and would be subject to release under FOIA.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning.; ; These efforts are important because they will facilitate our understanding of how the behavior of methamphetamine users may endanger herself/himself, others in the home or the immediate community, and law enforcement personnel. Greater knowledge about the characteristics of methamphetamine users and the ability to identify them is important because investigative and prosecutive decisions may be. affected if a defendant, a witness, or an informant has a drug abuse problem.
column5: Yes, this statement would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. The statement appears to be discussing internal agency efforts and strategies related to drug enforcement and prosecution, which could be considered privileged information. Additionally, the statement references the potential impact of drug abuse on legal proceedings, which could be considered sensitive information that agencies have a legitimate interest in protecting.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning.; ;     VI. Successes of Administration's Efforts.
column5: It is possible that the information in section VI could be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between government agencies. If the information in this section contains internal deliberations or communications related to the administration's efforts, it may be considered privileged and exempt from disclosure. However, if the information is purely factual and does not involve any privileged communications, it would not be protected under exemption 5. Ultimately, the determination of whether this section is exempt from disclosure would depend on the specific content of the information and the context in which it was created.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning.; ; The Administration believes that its vigorous efforts have led to a moderation in the trend of methamphetamine trafficking and abuse, based upon the same statistical criteria previously used. Initial reports from available statistical data indicate that methamphetamine use have shown a slight decline.  [ONDCP will provide recent DUF and DAWN figures which presumably show that methamphetamine use has decreased in all cities, except San Antonio. These figures are due out in May.).
column5: Yes, the statement would be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. The statement appears to be an internal communication within the Administration, discussing the effectiveness of its efforts to combat methamphetamine trafficking and abuse. As such, it could be considered a privileged communication that is exempt from disclosure under FOIA. Additionally, the mention of upcoming statistical data that has not yet been released could also be considered privileged information that is exempt from disclosure.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning.; ; Therefore, our continued efforts must remain vigilant and should be fortified.  We must be cautious not to relax such efforts, because our goals and objectives are not yet accomplished.   We need to continue a comprehensive assault against the dangers associated with methamphetamine production, distribution, trafficking, and abuse.
column5: No, the statement would not be protected under FOIA exemption 5. FOIA exemption 5 protects inter-agency or intra-agency communications that are deliberative in nature and would harm the decision-making process if disclosed. The statement provided does not appear to be a communication between agencies or within an agency, nor does it contain any deliberative information that would harm the decision-making process if disclosed. It is a general statement about the need to remain vigilant in the fight against methamphetamine production and abuse, which does not fall under the scope of exemption 5.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning.; ;     VII. Increased Resources Requested.
column5: No, the statement "Increased Resources Requested" would not be protected under FOIA exemption 5. Exemption 5 protects inter-agency or intra-agency communications that are privileged or confidential, such as attorney-client communications or deliberative process materials. However, the statement "Increased Resources Requested" does not fall under any of these categories and is not related to any privileged or confidential communication. It is a simple statement of fact and does not contain any deliberative or decision-making process. Therefore, it would not be protected under FOIA exemption 5.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning.; ; To demonstrate the Administration's continued efforts to combat the methamphetamine problem, it has requested significant additional resources be devoted to the threat.    A significant portion of the methamphetamine trafficking is occurring along the Southwest border.
column5: No, this statement would not be protected under FOIA exemption 5. FOIA exemption 5 protects inter-agency or intra-agency communications that are part of the decision-making process. This statement does not involve any communication between agencies or within an agency, nor does it involve any decision-making process. Therefore, it would not be protected under FOIA exemption 5.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning.; ; As part of the Administration's Southwest Border Initiative ["SWBI"), many DOJ components received significant resource enhancements in FY 1997.    The SWBI targets trafficking groups that manufacture and distribute methamphetamine as well as other drugs. In FY 1998 request, the U.S. Attorneys, DEA, and FBI are requesting a total of 359 positions [146 agents and 41 attorneys) and $46.8 million as part of the SWBI.   A significant portion of these resources have helped and will continue to assist in combatting the trafficking of methamphetamine.
column5: Yes, this would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. The language used in this passage suggests that it is discussing internal DOJ budget requests and resource allocation decisions, which would likely be considered privileged communications. Additionally, the passage does not appear to contain any information that would fall under other FOIA exemptions, such as personal privacy or national security concerns.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning.; ; The rise in methamphetamine trafficking has also caused an increased caseload for the U.S. Attorneys, and in response, the Administration's FY 1998 request for U.S. Attorneys includes an enhancement of 56 positions (37 attorneys) and $5,161,000 for its Narcotic and Dangerous Drug program.   In addition, the Administration is seeking three additional DOJ Criminal Division attorney positions in FY 1998 to increase its ability to coordinate and support the SWBI from headquarters.   These positions will support the Attorney General's goal to achieve enhanced centralized management of the investigations and prosecutions related to the large-scale, multi-district methamphetamine cases.
column5: This statement would not be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. The statement is a factual description of the Administration's request for funding and positions to address the increase in methamphetamine trafficking and support the Attorney General's goal. It does not contain any privileged legal or policy analysis or deliberative process.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning.; ; With respect to DEA, the FY 1998 budget request includes an increase of 74 positions (60 agents) and $11.1 million in resources to fund a comprehensive approach to combat methamphetamine trafficking. The FBI is focusing on identifying the most significant Mexican manufacturers and distributors of methamphetamine and targeting the key command and control elements of these organizations, including key distribution networks in small- and medium-sized U.S. communities.,  In addition, the FBI focuses its resources on methamphetamine distribution elements located in problem areas, such as Omaha, St. Louis, and Jackson.
column5: Yes, this information would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. The information provided appears to be internal agency communications regarding law enforcement strategies and tactics, which could be considered privileged and exempt from disclosure. Additionally, disclosing this information could potentially harm ongoing law enforcement efforts and compromise the safety of law enforcement personnel.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning.; ;     VIII. Conclusion.
column5: No, the conclusion would not be protected under FOIA exemption 5. FOIA exemption 5 pertains to privileged communications within or between agencies, such as attorney-client communications or deliberative process privilege. The conclusion of a document is typically a summary or final statement of the information presented, and does not fall under the scope of exemption 5.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning.; ; The Administration is dedicated to continuing its efforts to stop the spread of methamphetamine trafficking and abuse in this country.  The Administration will continue its cooperative efforts with the U.S. Conference of Mayors ["USCM") in contributing to their "National Action Plan To Control Drugs." One of their top priorities has been to increase public awareness of the methamphetamine threat, and the USCM fully supports the Administration's initiative to combat the spread of methamphetamine.    Federal authorities will continue to investigate and prosecute cases aggressively, as well as promulgate strong regulations, provide training to state and local agencies, promote public awareness of the problem, and educate and treat methamphetamine users.
column5: No, this statement would not be protected under FOIA exemption 5. Exemption 5 applies to inter-agency or intra-agency communications that are privileged or confidential, such as attorney-client communications or deliberative process materials. This statement does not appear to fall under either of those categories and is instead a public statement about the Administration's efforts to combat methamphetamine trafficking and abuse.
